creator: Steiner, Frank J. (photographer)
description: Spectators line First Street and Santa Clara Street near the Bank of America building to watch the Baby Parade. Babies are seated in decorated carriages; women are pulling or escorting these small floats. Banners, bunting and flags are on buildings and are strung across the streets. This was the seventh annual Fiesta de las Rosas parade.

subject: Buildings; Children; Events; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Men; Parades & processions; Spectators; Streets; Women
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: Title float on which the parade queen and her attendants are riding. Queen Emilia Lindeman is seated beneath an umbrella interwoven with sweet peas and roses and a pathway of ferns below. There are wide strips of red and white roses arranged in an alternating diamond design. Two huge trees covered with pink roses were placed on each side of the throne. The queen's attendants on the steps leading down from the throne were Miss Gilroy, Clara Filice; Miss Los Gatos, Phyllis Cole; Miss Saratoga, Lutheria Cunningham; Miss Morgan Hill, Alice Speele; Miss Palo Alto, Doretta Griffin; Miss Mountain View, Vera Dean; Miss Sunnyvale, Martha Carlson; Miss Los Altos, Alta Miller; Miss Santa Clara, Frances Weigand. Crowds of people are watching. There is a house and cars in the background.
relation: Fiesta de las Rosas Photographic Album, 1929

subject: Buildings; Children; Events; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Men; Parades & processions; Spectators; Streets; Women
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float was called "The Court of Childhood" and was dedicated to the spirit of youth. The queen of the float, Jean Floy Thomas, is seated at the top looking down from a throne with an arch made by a rope of flowers. There are fourteen other children other than the queen and all on the float are dressed in white. There are also what appear to be three fake doves sitting on branches at the front of the float. Crowds of people are watching.

subject: Buildings; Children; Events; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Men; Parades & processions; Spectators; Streets; Women
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: "Safety first in school territory" is the description accompanying this image. This float was entered by Captain William Emig, chief of the San Jose's traffic office at the time. Spelled out in flowers is a caption that says "school zone 15 miles." Additionally, a speedometer six feet high, with an arrow pointed to the number 15 and made of flowers is featured on the float. The speedometer overlooks a mock playground with a slide and seesaw. Children are playing on the slide and seesaw. Crowds of people are watching. There is a house in the background.

subject:

Tournament of Roses Association
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float, called the "Kingdom of Flowers," was designed as a Japanese pleasure barge and was described as representative of the languid beauty of Nippon. It was entered by the Pasadena Tournament of Roses, Inc. The float is banked with thousands of carnations, roses, sweet peas, corn-flowers, delphinium and huckleberries. The barge has a flower studded pergola and women are sitting in it. Crowds of people are watching. There are houses and cars in the background.

subject: Buildings; Children; Events; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Men; Parades & processions; Spectators; Streets; Women
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float, based on the book "Whither Mankind," by historian Charles Austin Beard, symbolized international peace as realized through education. The float featured "a battleship of peace" with a mass of flowers, organ pipes used for a smoke stack, an airplane at the prow, depicting the future, and a group of children from various schools representing the nations of the world. The boat was built of white sweet peas, delphinium, and wild flowers. Crowds of people are watching them. There are houses and cars in the background.

subject:
Buildings; Children; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Women
Fresno Chamber of Commerce
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float was called "Fresno Scenic Center of California," and was entered by the Fresno Chamber of Commerce. Representing a mountain scene, the float is steeped with ferns interwoven with mountain flowers, all of which were gathered in the hills. This float does not appear to be on The Alameda. There are three girls sitting on the float and several onlookers. In the background are houses and a field with cars parked. All of the girls have straw hats draped around their necks with rope.

subject:
Buildings; Children; Events; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Horses; Men; Parades & processions; Spectators; Streets; Universities & colleges; Women
San Jose State Teachers College
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float, enterted by San Jose State Teachers College's associated students, and called "The Horse of Troy," symbolized the courage and spirit of Sparta. The horse, which stood 14 feet high, was amassed with white roses and stood on a sled banked in roses varying in shade from deep red to pink. The float is pulled by men dressed in ancient Spartan costumes. The men are holding battle shields. Two men at the front hold a banner which says "The Horse of Troy San Jose State Teachers College." There are houses, crowds of people, and a line of cars in the background.

creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float, a Native American tepee, was made of various shades of yellow flowers, with the top made of white roses. The float is being pulled by a horse and has two boys sitting on the float dressed in Native American costumes. One boy role plays as an elder teaching the other boy how to shoot a bow and arrow. It depicts Hiawatha shooting his first arrow. There is a house and crowds of people in the background.

creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float, called "Queen Violet Ray," has a huge circle in which green, white and violet flowers in the rear form the throne for Queen Violet Ray and her two attendents. Two female attendents in shorts are on either side of the the queen. In front of the queen are three women in black bathing suits with three men dressed in a mariachi-style costumes facing the women and are playing guitars. There is a house and crowds of people in the background.

creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: It is unknown if this car was entered by an organization. The car is sparsely decorated with a banner of what appears to be bells with bows at the top. There are two children standing on the outside of the car hanging off the sides. The driver is not visible. Three women and one man are sitting in the vehicle. The woman nearest the front is holding a flowered tamborine. All the people are dressed in Californio/Mexican costumes. A United States flag hangs over the grill of the car. There are crowds of people in the background.

Chamber of Commerce (Los Gatos, Calif.)
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float called "Puss 'n Boots" was entered by the Los Gatos Chamber of Commerce and was based on the fairytale by the same name. It is a large boot covered with marigolds and poppies surrounded by greens and other flowers. On the float at the front is a vaquero playing a xylophone and directly behind are two children dressed as cats with a man in a sailor costume between them. In the very back of the float is the boot with another child dressed as a cat standing in the boot. Crowds of people are watching. There is a house in the background.

Richfield Oil Company
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: This float displays the beacon stations of the Richfield Oil Company. Also on the float is a Richfield racing car made of carnations (a replica similar to the car used in the company's road advertising) as well as a miniature service station following Spanish architecture. One woman sits above the miniature service station at the back of the float and two other women sit below her. At the front of the float is a woman standing in a costume that appears to be a racing costume. There are houses in the background.

subject: Airplanes; Buildings; Events; Floats (Parades); Flowers; Men; Organizations; Parades & processions; Spectators; Streets; Women
creator: Frank J. Steiner (photographer)
description: Sponsored by the San Jose Chamber of Commerce, this float is an airplane made of green shrubs more than 20 feet long and a wing span of 19 feet. On the side of the fusilage is the name "San Jose" in white flowers. The fusilage was finished with sweet williams. Green huckleberry was used in decorating the wings. A propeller made of flowers was kept in constant motion. Two men standing on the street in front of the float hold a banner which says "San Jose must have an airport this year." A boy sits in the pilot seat looking out. There is a house and spectators in the background.

Frontier Village
creator: Associated Press
description: Bing Croby's son celebrating third birthday. Sitting at table with birthday cake and decorations from left to right is Bing Crosby, his son Nathaniel Crosby, wife Cathy Crosby, and daughter Mary Francis Crosby. Nathaniel is blowing out candles on birthday cake as the others look on. Caption on photograph says,"(FX5) San Jose, Calif., Oct. 26--The Big Blow--Bing Crosby's youngest son, Nathaniel, is set to blow out his birthday candles at his third birthday party, held Saturday at Frontier Village in suburban San Jose. With the senior Crosby and son are Mrs. Cathy Crosby and daughter Mary Frances, 4. The group spent the day at Frontier Village, a family amusement park of 33 acres. (APWirephoto)(b21700ho) 1964."

description: One of several Frontier Village wanted posters. This one features a character named Mad Millie. She is standing with a rifle in her hands with one of her feet propped up on a man lying on the ground. She is wearing a western-style dress, cowboy boots with spurs, and a cowboy hat. In the background is a cactus and a cow skull. Above the sketch of Mad Millie it says "Wanted." Underneath the sketch it says "alias Mad Millie reward 50 buckskins." Also, there is a narrative that explains Mad Millie's background.

Frontier Village
creator: Unknown
description: This direct mail marketing flyer offers group discounts for groups ranging from 10 to 2000 people. It is styled as a wanted poster and delineates the main features and amusements that Frontier Village has to offer. The flyer is white, with a brownish trim and black writing. The bottom of the flyer is detachable and is meant to be mailed in four days prior to a particular group's planned visit. It asks for details such as date and time of arrival, name of group, group plan desired, number of persons, and method of payment.

subject:
Clothing & dress; Children; Dance; Dancers; Indigenous peoples; Men; Tipis
Eagle dance; UPITN Corporation
Frontier Village
description: This photograph is identified with what appears to be a United Press International index number which is listed as SXP052206S. This is written along with the caption at the bottom of the photograph on the front. The exact location is unknown but it is somewhere in San Jose, California. The image is of a two year old boy named James Firguson of Mountain View, California, learning the eagle dance from a Native American from the Kiowa named Lanny Quoetone. Both are standing in front of a tipi. James Firguson is facing Lanny Quoetone and is mimicking his movement. Lanny Quoetone is bending slightly with arms outstretched as if he way flying and he is wearing traditional Native American clothing.

Frontier Village
creator: Unknown
description: This is the inside of a Frontier Village employee picnic flyer. In the middle is a picture of a man lying on his side with his head propped up on his arm. He is dressed like a woman and is wearing a flowered mini dress and a wig.  Underneath him is a caption that says "Miss Picnic 1970." There are also four smaller pictures surrounding the middle picture. Clockwise they are:  a man playing a banjo, a young boy on a carousel, a young girl eating a snow cone, and picnic table with men and women seated at it eating.

creator: Thompson, George H. (cartographer)
description: Map of lands confirmed as belonging to the Pueblo of San Jose. After incorporation, these lands were sold by the city of San Jose to pay municipal debts. Relief is shown by hachures. description: Atlas of the major agricultural regions of Santa Clara County in the 1880s. This atlas does not cover urban areas, nor agricultural areas in the southern part of the county. Each regional map shows property lines, number of acres, and the name of the property owner. Some of the regional maps have supplemental information, describing the area in general and giving the kinds of crops grown on each property. The maps and supplemental information were originally published in issues of Pacific Tree and Vine Magazine.

source: SJPL California Room Map & Atlas Collection
description: Atlas of the major agricultural regions of Santa Clara County in the 1880s. This atlas does not cover urban areas, nor agricultural areas in the southern part of the county. Each regional map shows property lines, number of acres, and the name of the property owner. Some of the regional maps have supplemental information, describing the area in general and giving the kinds of crops grown on each property. The maps and supplemental information were originally published in issues of Pacific Tree and Vine Magazine.

subject: Automobile racing; Automobiles; Carriages & coaches; Celebrations; Events; Men; Spectators; Women
creator: Unknown
description: Crowds are gathered for the arrival of the "Thomas Flyer," at the Lamotte House, northeast corner of Santa Clara Street and San Pedro Street. To get a better view, four women stand on the seats of a car. The 1908 New York to Paris Automobile Race was sponsored by the New York Times and Le Matin. National teams competed. The American team, driving a car manufactured by the E. R. Thomas Motor Company, won.

title: Thomas Flyer, New York to Paris Race, in San Jose.

subject: Hotels; Trees
creator: Unknown
description: View of the "Sentinel Tree" and one of the earliest San Jose hotels beside it, as they both appeared in 1904. At that time, the sycamore was thought to be about 400 years old. It was a landmark to settlers in the 1840s, an indication that they had arrived in San Jose. Formerly twice as tall as it appears in this photograph, the top half cracked off in a storm in the 1890s. It was finally taken down in March 2000, because the owners feared it would fall onto to their 1950s era house. It stood at 590 North 21st Street.

His country house still stands at Fourteenth Street and San Fernando Street.  The estate was subdivided in 1902 and it is now known as the neighborhood, Naglee Park.

creator: Unknown
description: Front view of the home in which poet and teacher Edwin Markham (1852-1940) lived with his mother in the 1890s. Markham's room, with the bay window (on left side of the photograph), is known as "The Hoe Room."

The Clark estate extended to Stockton Avenue to the east, covering seven acres, and stood until about 1920.

subject:

Hobson, David, 1822-1916; Society of Friends -- History
creator: Unknown
description: David Hobson was born in North Carolina in 1822. He came to California in 1850 as a prospector, did well and settled in San Jose in 1853. He and his brother, Jessie, established the first Quaker Society of Friends in San Jose in 1861. He married in 1866 and he and his wife, Mary, eventually had eleven children. The family farm was at King and Mabury Road. He died there in 1916.

Fresno (Calif.) -- History
Church, Moses James
creator: Unknown
description: Portrait of Moses James Church, who is considered the father of irrigation in the San Joaquin Valley. He came to Fresno in the 1860s and it was there that he devised the first irrigation system. He also built the first flour mill in Fresno; raised grain, sheep and cattle; and, was a prominent member of the Seventh Day Adventist Church. He built the first such church in Fresno.

subject:

Clark, William Squire; Clark, William Squire, Jr., 1886-1898
creator: Wright (photographic studio)
description: William Squire Clark, Jr. (1886-1898), affectionately known as "Squire" to his family, at 20 months old. He was the last child, and only son, of William Sr. and Alice Duncan Clark, who also had four daughters: Isabella, Alice, Mary and Grace. William Jr. died in 1898 at the age of 12. His eldest sister Isabella's suicide in 1903 was at least partially attributed to the fact that she never got over young "Squire's" death.

description: Photograph of an engraving. Charles Fayette "Mac" McGlashan (1847-1931) was a well-liked and respected renaissance man who is credited with being a writer, editor, scientist, lawyer, inventor, legislator and amateur entomologist. Among many accomplishments, he is most known for his well-researched book, The History of the Donner Party, and also for inventing a means of communicating with moving trains.

description: Adolph Sutro, in profile, with example of his autograph. An engineer, his work in mines on the Comstock Lode made him a millionaire. Sutro was a mayor of San Francisco. creator: Harliss & Franklin (photographic studio)

Lick, James, 1796-1876
creator: Unknown

On the west bank of the Guadalupe River, about a quarter mile north of Montague Road.

creator: Hare, Alice Iola, 1859-1942 (photographer)
description: Group of fourteen Japanese orchard workers sit, gathered around a large pile of Tussock moth cocoons. The cocoons had to be removed from the trees by hand in the days before pesticides. The man is writing in a small notebook, perhaps tallying up the number of cocoons picked by each worker.

subject:

Arbuckle, Clyde, 1903-1998
Cook, George; Muller, Mary Little
creator: Unknown
description: Clyde Arbuckle, Mary Little Mueller and George Cook in Santa Barbara as part of the Argonaut Field Trips, a locally-organized series of historic tours throughout the state and occasionally abroad. Arbuckle was the narrator of these tours, which were an extension of his Metropolitan Adult Education classes on historical subjects. Mueller organized the trips and Cook was the bus driver. Arbuckle taught the Adult Education classes, and led the tours.

subject:
Cemeteries; Tombs & sepulchral monuments
Chinese -- California -- History
creator: Unknown
description: Scene of a former Chinese cemetery in Bakersfield, California. Over the years, the grounds were not maintained, many graves collapsed and the site was overgrown with weeds. In the 1950s, the Chinese community decided to move the graves - a total of 261 - to another resting place. Only forty-three of the remains could be identified.  It took two years to complete the relocation.

creator: Unknown
description: Photograph of a lithograph (created by Henry C. Eno) of Samuel Emmons Hollister (1817-1876) fighting with a bear, in a famous encounter in the Sierra Nevada Mountains. Hollister, originally from Saratoga, New York, was a California pioneer who captured bears for exhibit in New York.

subject:
Events; Historical markers; Monuments & memorials
Hill, Andrew Putnam, 1853-1922; Big Basin Redwoods State Park (Calif." Conservationists, American
creator: Unknown
description: Memorial tablet reads: "In memory of the public service of Andrew P. Hill 1853-1922" and "He saved the redwoods." The original fountain of stone, surmounted by this same bronze tablet, stood near the present-day photographic studio and was dedicated May 30, 1924. It had to be removed when Big Basin Redwoods State Park's roads and buildings were rearranged by the Civilian Service Corps. The memorial was rededicated on July 14, 1946.

subject: Buildings; Carts & Wagons; Men; Mining; Oxen; Smelters
creator: Unknown
description: Men with ox-drawn carts wait outside an industrial building. View of Oreana, Nevada, which came into being in 1865 as a smelting center, where ore was treated from the nearby Montezuma Mine. At its peak, Oreana was the largest producer of bullion in the state with $45,000 per month. However, it had outlived its usefulness by 1870 and saw little activity after. Today, mill and smelter ruins, foundations and slag piles are left.

subject:
Automobiles; Buildings; Events; Men; Military officers; Parades & processions; Political pageantry; Spectators; Stores & shops; Women
United States. Navy -- Cruise, 1907-1909
creator: Unknown
description: Photograph of a parade of naval officers approaching Meridian Corners. A line of cars is carrying the officers west down Stevens Creek Boulevard from the direction of San Jose. They are welcomed by a small crowd of people at Meridian Corners, a cluster of buildings at the corner of Stevens Creek Boulevard and Saratoga Avenue. Some people are standing while others sit in automobiles or carriages. In the foreground a woman stands in the rear seat of a car decorated with American flags. The naval officers were attached to the Great White Fleet which was then anchored in San Francisco Bay. The officers had arrived earlier that day by train and after lunch were being given an automobile tour of Santa Clara County.

creator: Unknown

This road led from San Jose to Lick Observatory. A group of ladies sits on the front steps of the hotel. Two gentleman stand on the veranda behind them. The standing man on the right may be Thomas Snell, owner and builder of the hotel. Another gentleman stands to the left of the ladies. subject: Men; Railroad accidents; Railroads; Women
creator: Unknown
description: Photograph of a railroad derailment that took place in Santa Clara on August 28, 1899. Two engines derailed here, although one is under No. 1377 and cannot be seen. These two trains in tandem were pulling a heavy load of passengers returning from Monterey. They derailed at this intersection of broad and narrow gauge railroad tracks when a switchman switched the track to narrow gauge without realizing a broad gauge train was fast approaching. There were a few minor injuries but no one was seriously hurt. A large crowd is milling around examining the wreck. Note that many of the men have their train tickets tucked into their hatbands. In the background is the Santa Clara Depot as well as two trains unable to proceed.

subject:

Native Daughters of the Golden West; Statehood (American politics)
Brohaska, Tillie, d. 1948
creator: Unknown
description: Photograph of a group of women from the Native Daughters of the Golden West participating in the 1907 Admissions Day parade in San Jose. A few women are on horseback but most are riding in carriages. They are stopped on South Market Street near the intersection of Post Street. The woman sitting in the first carriage peering over the shoulder of the man with the cigar is Tillie Brohaska, member of the musical Brohaska family and a well known local pianist. She was also a charter member of the Vendome Parlor, Native Daughters of the Golden West in San Jose.

subject:
Buildings; Hospitals; Mental institutions
Agnews State Hospital (San Jose, Calif.)
creator: Unknown
description: Photograph of the Agnews State Asylum for the Insane shortly after its construction in 1888. A photographer and camera stand in the dirt road leading to the main entrance of the asylum. The asylum consisted of an administration building in the center flanked on either side by wings housing more than 900 patients. The building was 750 feet long and was constructed at a cost of $750,000. Much of the stone and masonry building collapsed during the 1906 earthquake, killing 11 staff members and 101 patients.

subject:
Agricultural facilities; Crimes; Homicides; Serial murderers

McGlincy, Richard P., d.1896; Dunham, James
creator: Unknown
description: Photograph of the McGlincy house and barn, site of a mass murder on May 26, 1896. James Dunham murdered his wife, stepfather, mother-in-law, brother-in-law, the family maid, and a farm hand. James Dunham fled and was never caught. The house where most of the murders were committed is on the left. A horse and carriage waits outside the house. Another carriage can be seen through one of the open barn doors. The house was demolished in 1955.

subject:
Buildings; Men; Grocery stores; Post offices

Smythe, D. W.; Winlow, Albert E.
creator: Unknown
description: Black-and-white photograph of the Kensington Post Office, Willow Glen. Between Jan. 14, 1893 and Jan. 14, 1895, all mail addressed to residents of Kensington, California, went to the Kensington Post Office, housed in this grocery store on the northeast corner of Minnesota and Cherry avenues in what is now San Jose. This post office bore the name Kensington until it became Willowglen in 1895. It continued as Willowglen until the transferring of its mail service to San Jose on Jan. 15, 1900. It continued to house a store until razed to make way for Station 6 of the San Jose Fire Department, built in 1963. The bearded man in the photo is probably Postmaster Albert E. Winlow who, with D. W. Smythe, operated the grocery store under the name of A. E. Winlow & Co." Grocery items can be seen stacked on the porch and in the windows.
rights: Material in the public domain. No restrictions on use. For more information on copyright or permissions for this image, please contact the California Room: http://www.sjlibrary.org/research/special/ca/contacts_index.htm

subject:
Art; Buildings; Business enterprises; Engravings; Horse railroads; Pedestrians; Storefronts; Stores & shops
Goodrich, Levi I., 1822-1887
creator: Unknown
description: Engraving of the Knox Building, also called the Knox Block. The Knox Building stood at the northwest corner of First Street and Santa Clara Street. It was constructed in 1866, and demolished in 1945. Businesses housed in the Knox Building included: a real estate office, a musical instruments shop, the Feist Brothers' dry goods store and two cigar shops.  A doctor, a contractor, lawyers and architect Levi Goodrich had offices on the second floor. Note the San Jose Library on the second floor at far right. Horse drawn trolleys pass through a busy intersection. This engraving is from Thompson & West's 1876 Historical Atlas of Santa Clara County.

subject: Agricultural laborers; Agricultural machinery & implements; Agriculture; Farming; Farms; Men
creator: Unknown
description: Four men spraying trees in an orchard for pest control. On verso of photo: "Keeping an orchard healthy called for a lot of work. It meant spraying, dusting, pruning, irrigating, or some other form of attention almost the year around. Deer sometimes proved pests to orchardists in the foothill areas, but brown rot, shot hole borer, leaf curl, San Jose scale and oak root fungus evoked a lot more profanity. This photo shows a spray crew at work in an orchard, a common sight in the valley every year just before the trees came into bloom and foliage."

subject:
Adobe buildings; Buildings; Storage facilities
Peralta, Luis Maria, 1759-1851
Gonzalez, Manuel, d. 1804
creator: Unknown
description: The Peralta Adobe is the oldest surviving structure in San Jose and its only surviving adobe. It was restored in 1976 as part of the Bicentennial celebration. In this 1947 photograph it is unrestored with a tin roof and serving as a storehouse for plumbing supplies. The Peralta Adobe is a San Jose Historic Landmark, a California Historical Landmark and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The adobe was most likely built by Manuel Gonzalez, a member of the Anza Party and a founder of the Pueblo de San Jose de Guadalupe. Luis Maria Peralta came to San Jose in 1807 when he was named comisionado of the Pueblo.

creator: Cann (photographic studio)
description: Lieutenant Jesse J. Adel, 1817-1933. We know that Jesse Adel was a lifelong resident of San Jose; he is buried at The Presidio in San Francisco. Help us confirm that Jesse Adel, a clerk, salesman and soldier, was also an artist.

subject: Automobiles; Men; Parades & processions; Women
creator: Unknown
description: Los Gatos held a Floral Carnival and Feast of Lanterns for May Day 1909. Festivities included a parade of vehicles decorated with flowers. Mrs. J. R. Welch won a trophy for "Best Decorated Auto driven by a Lady." Her 1908 Rambler was bedecked with pink roses and gauze butterflies. Mrs. Welch sits at the wheel of her car with her husband Judge J. R. Welch at her side. In the second seat, Camellia March, Judge Fred B. Brown and Jane Marsh are seated. In the back seat, Mrs. Brown, Judge John E. Richards and Mrs. Richards are seated. The Rambler is parked in front of Interurban Railroad cars.
rights: Material in the public domain. No restrictions on use. For more information on copyright or permissions for this image, please contact the California Room: http://www.sjlibrary.org/research/special/ca/contacts_index.htm

subject: Buildings; City & town halls; Municipal government; Pedestrians; Sculpture; Women
creator: Unknown
description: Women walk toward City Hall. This was San Jose's Old City Hall before demolition. It stood in Plaza Park, now known as Plaza de César Chávez, where the children's fountain is located. The building housed city offices and the police department used the basement. In use since 1889, the building was demolished in June 1958. Statue in foreground is of Dr. Henry D. Cogswell, a prohibitionist. It stood atop the drinking fountain he donated to the city.

subject:

San Jose State College; San Jose State University
creator: Unknown
description: An aerial view of San Jose in 1940, looking north. Spartan Stadium is in the foreground, surrounded by open land. At center left, the Sacred Heart of Jesus Parish is seen on Willow Street. Downtown San Jose is in the center of the photograph: the Hotel DeAnza and the Bank of America building are identifiable. The thirteen-story Medico-Dental Building stands at East Santa Clara Street and North Sixth Street and San Jose State is one block to the south, at Washington Square. In the distance, a hanger at Moffett Field in Sunnyvale is seen (center, background).

Notre Dame High School
creator: Unknown
description: View of very large two-story house on a corner lot with bare trees lining the streets.  This was Judge Myles P. O'Connor's house. It stood at the corner of Second Street and Reed Street. Midway School
creator: Unknown
description: A class photograph at Midway School in Alviso. In this photograph, boys and girls of various ages pose with their teacher outside of their school building. Unlike other class photographs during this time period, the boys are dressed dissimilarly wearing several different styles including longs pants, overalls, and suspenders. The boy in the center of the photo holds a black dog in his arms. This casual dress and combined age class is indicative of a small rural school.

Lincoln School
creator: Tucker, John O. (photographer)
description: Full exterior shot of Lincoln school taken from across the street. A horse and cart is parked in the mud in front of the school and an American flag waves in the wind. Lincoln School was built around the 1870's, more classrooms were added in 1895, and it survived the 1906 earthquake that destroyed several other schools. The building was eventually torn down in 1975.
